[File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: EVENT_PROCESSING_LOOP_BUSY_DURATION_S] [Panic on Initialization] If the register_histogram!() macro fails and unwrap() panics during lazy initialization, can this cause validator nodes to crash at startup or during runtime when the metric is first accessed, leading to loss of liveness? [File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: EVENT_PROCESSING_LOOP_BUSY_DURATION_S] [Observability Blind Spot] Does the duration histogram only track 'busy' time, potentially hiding malicious activity that occurs during 'idle' periods, allowing attackers to exploit discovery protocol weaknesses without detection? [File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: EVENT_PROCESSING_LOOP_BUSY_DURATION_S] [Time Manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate system time or clock skew to poison the duration measurements, causing incorrect busy time calculations that hide performance degradation attacks or create false alerting? [File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: EVENT_PROCESSING_LOOP_BUSY_DURATION_S] [Metric Poisoning] If malicious discovery events cause extremely long processing times, can the histogram become saturated with outlier values that obscure legitimate performance issues and prevent operators from detecting consensus slowdowns? [File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: DISCOVERY_COUNTS] [Race Condition] Can concurrent increments to DISCOVERY_COUNTS from multiple threads processing discovery events simultaneously cause race conditions where counter values become inconsistent, hiding actual peer discovery counts and masking network partition attacks? [File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: DISCOVERY_COUNTS] [Integer Overflow] Can an attacker cause the IntCounterVec values to overflow by repeatedly triggering discovery events over extended time periods, causing counter wraparound that resets metrics to zero and hides persistent network attacks? [File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: DISCOVERY_COUNTS] [Information Leakage] Do the 'role_type', 'network_id', and 'peer_id' labels expose sensitive validator topology information that attackers can scrape from metrics endpoints to map the network, identify high-value targets, and plan targeted attacks? [File: aptos-core/network/discovery/src/counters.rs] [Metric: DISCOVERY_COUNTS] [Panic on Initialization] If register_int_counter_vec!() fails and unwrap() panics, can this crash validator nodes during initialization or when first accessed, causing immediate loss of liveness for validators attempting to join the network?
